question: Question_01_(a)
statement:
Let \emph{PA = LU} be

\[\begin{bmatrix}
1 &0 &0 \\ 
0& 0 &1 \\ 
0& 1 &0 
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
1& 0 &2 &3 \\ 
2& 1 & 8 & 8\\ 
0& 1& 4 & 2
\end{bmatrix}
= \begin{bmatrix}
1& 0 &0 \\ 
0& 1& 0\\ 
2& 1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
1 &0 &2 &3 \\ 
0& 1 & 4 &2 \\ 
0& 0 &0 &0 
\end{bmatrix}\]

and

\[b = \begin{bmatrix}
b_1 \\ b_2 \\ b_3
\end{bmatrix}\]

\textbf{(a)} Find a basis for each of the four fundamental subspaces.
sols:
This matrix \emph{A} in this question is given in the form of an
\emph{LU} decomposition with partial pivoting where \emph{P} is just the
matrix which swaps the rows of \emph{A}. The matrix \emph{P} also would
not affect \emph{R(A)}, \emph{N(A)}, \emph{R(A\textsuperscript{T})}
where we need to look at the matrix \emph{U} (echelon form) to find the
bases.

To find a basis for the \emph{R(A)}, we must identify the pivot columns
in matrix \emph{U}, which turns out to be the first and second column.

The pivots are highlighted in red.

\[U = \begin{bmatrix}
{\color{Red}{1}} & 0 & 2 &3 \\ 0& {\color{Red}{1}} &4 &2 \\ 
0 &0 &0 &0 
\end{bmatrix}\]

The basis for \emph{R(A)} is then the corresponding columns in \emph{A}
to the pivot columns in \emph{U}.

The pivot columns of \emph{A} are highlighted in red.

\[A = \begin{bmatrix}
{\color{Red}{1}} & {\color{Red}{0}}& 2& 3\\ {\color{Red}{2}}& {\color{Red}{1}} & 8 &8 \\ 
{\color{Red}{0}}& {\color{Red}{1}} & 4 & 2\end{bmatrix}\]

\[R(A) = \text{span}\left(
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\2 
\\0 
\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}
0\\1 
\\1 
\end{bmatrix}\right)\]

To find \emph{N(A)}, we can set $Ux=0$ and solve for \emph{x}. This
would give us 2 equations and 2 free variables.

\begin{align*}
x_1 &= -2x_3 - 3x_4 \\
x_2 &= -4x_3 - 2x_4 \\
x_3 &= x_3 \\
x_4 &= x_4
\end{align*}

\[x = x_3\begin{bmatrix}
-2\\ 
-4\\ 
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+
x_4\begin{bmatrix}
-3\\ 
-2\\ 
0\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}\]

And therefore

\[N(A) = \text{span}\left(
\begin{bmatrix}
-2\\ 
-4\\ 
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}
-3\\ 
-2\\ 
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\right)\]

The basis of \emph{R(A\textsuperscript{T})} can be taken from the rows
of \emph{U} that contain pivots.

\[R(A^T) = \text{span}\left(
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
0\\ 
2\\ 
3
\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
1\\ 
4\\ 
2
\end{bmatrix}\right)\]

To find the basis for \emph{N(A\textsuperscript{T})}, we must row reduce
\emph{A\textsuperscript{T}} and solve for \emph{x} in $A^Tx = 0$

From row reducing \emph{A\textsuperscript{T}}, you should acquire the
matrix

\[\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & -2\\ 
0& 1 & 1\\ 
0& 0 & 0\\ 
0& 0 & 0
\end{bmatrix}\]

Solving for \emph{x}, you end up with 2 equations and 1 free variable.

\begin{align*}
x_1 &= 2x_3 \\
x_2 &= -x_3 \\
x_3 &= x_3
\end{align*}

\[x = x_3\begin{bmatrix}
2\\ 
-1\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}\]

And hence

\[N(A^T) = \text{span}\left(
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\ 
-1\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}\right)\]
